Award.AwardTitle: Experimental Evaluation and Modeling of Hydraulic Flocculation Systems Under Conditions of Turbulent Flow

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1437961
Lion

Experimental Evaluation and Modeling of Hydraulic Flocculation Systems under Conditions of Turbulent Flow

The overall goal of this project is to make resilient water treatment technologies that are the most economical for application in the global south and the highest performing for application in industrialized countries. Hydraulic flocculation requires no electricity, has no moving parts, and is a key component of resilient high performing treatment of surface water and of arsenic contaminated groundwater. The proposed research will create and test a mechanistically based model for turbulent flow hydraulic flocculation and to use that model as a basis for optimizing hydraulic flocculator design. The research performed under this project will be integrated into the AguaClara program at Cornell University. This integration ensures a high level of undergraduate involvement in the research and rapid transfer of the research results into scalable design algorithms and then to implementation partners in other countries who build AguaClara facilities for communities in need of safe drinking water. The hands-on research and design experience with an international context creates an engineering education that changes lives. The fundamental understanding resulting from this research will improve the performance of robust gravity powered, water treatment plants and will reduce costs.

The large range of relevant length scales (nm to m) and the turbulent and laminar flow regimes that occur in sequential processes used for water treatment have resulted in an empirical approach to design that does not correctly scale to the flows applicable to small communities (1,000 to 50,000 individuals). In the proposed research, theoretical analysis coupled with experimental evaluation will be used to identify the dominant parameters and mechanisms affecting the growth and breakup of flocculent particles, and their distribution of sedimentation velocities. Most previous work on flocculation has utilized mechanically-stirred reactors with poorly characterized and highly heterogeneous energy dissipation rates. This project will use well-characterized turbulent tube flow flocculators and turbulent serpentine baffled flow reactors (characterized by computational fluid dynamics (CFD)). Core components of the proposed model have already been created through studies of flocculation under laminar flow and reveal a composite dependence of flocculation on floc volume fraction, colloid surface coverage by coagulant (both dependent on influent turbidity and coagulant type and dose), and reactor conditions (energy dissipation rate, hydraulic residence time). Specialized instrumentation has also been constructed that permits non-destructive analysis of flocculent particle settling velocities, video monitoring of solids concentration over a wide range of time and spatial scales within experimental reactors, and automation of experiments which allows exploration of a greater range of parameter space than would otherwise be possible.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Flocculation is a core drinking water treatment process that enables production of high quality drinking water from surface and groundwater sources that are contaminated with particles and pathogens.

Flocculation is the process of adding sticky nanoparticles to a suspension of microscopic particles including clay and pathogens and then causing the particles to aggregate into flocs (like snowflakes in water)  that settle quickly to be removed from the water. The nanoparticles are transported by diffusion and fluid deformation to the particle surfaces. Flocculators generate turbulence that ultimately is dissipated as fluid deformation. This fluid deformation causes the particles to move relative to each other and the particles collide as they slide past each other.

The focus of our research over the past 15 years has been to develop a fundamental understanding of the flocculation process so that we could begin to optimize the design of flocculators to use less energy and to eliminate moving parts so that more communities could benefit from safe water on tap.

In this NSF research project we discovered that both turbulent and laminar flow flocculators are described by the same flocculation model. This is because the particle collisions in both cases are dominated by the fluid deformation that is controlled by the energy input and the fluid viscosity. The flocculation model was validated for both types of flows and the model was extended to incorporate the effects of natural organic matter. These new insights are opening up new opportunities to begin to set coagulant dosages based on a model that captures the fundamental physics of the process.

This research is based on the insight that coagulant nanoparticles used in drinking water treatment plants are highly surface active and readily form bonds with many types of surfaces. This was one of the key insights that led to the AguaClara Hydraulic Flocculation Model. Another insight was that in shear flow, particle collisions only occur between particles of similar size.

The AguaClara Hydraulic Flocculation Model was coupled with reactor design to invent a new high efficiency hydraulic flocculator. Traditional mechanized flocculators as well as early designs for AguaClara hydraulic flocculators use energy inefficiently to produce particle collisions. Traditional flocculators also have regions of very high velocity gradients that are many times larger than the average velocity gradient. Maintaining a relatively uniform velocity gradient has been particularly challenging in focculators with flows less than about 10 L/s. The AguaClara Cornell team invented a design approach and a flocculator geometry that ensures that the maximum velocity gradient is only 1.4 times larger than the average velocity gradient even for flocculators that are treating water for villages.  

The new hydraulic flocculator design ensures that a flow contraction and expansion occurs as soon as the flow has fully expanded from the previous contraction. This invention makes it possible to build more compact and less expensive flocculators. This new design has already been incorporated into 6 community scale water treatment plants in Honduras and Nicaragua. 

The flocculation research is strongly influenced by feedback from our community partner organization, Agua Para el Pueblo, in Honduras. They provide the motivation to create better performing and more sustainable alternatives so that more communities can afford and maintain water treatment facilities. DUring the course of this research project 12 additional AguaClara water treatment plants that rely on hydraulic flocculation were designed, built, and began providing safe water on tap to over 40,000 people.

The AguaClara Cornell team has continued to grow and has between 80 and 100 undergraduate students each semester that are researching, inventing, and designing new and improved water treatment technologies. This is in addition to the graduate students who are funded by NSF. These undergraduate students are a vital part of the invention process as they develop better reactor geometries, test hypotheses about how to best remove various contaminants from water, and are creating the next generation of the AguaClara Infrastructure Design Engine.
